title: RS22623
content: The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement, survivors, disability, unemployment, and sickness benefits for railroad workers and their families. Workers covered by the RRB system include those employed by railroads engaged in interstate commerce. The RRB system is separate from Social Security but closely coordinated. Insured railroad workers receive RRB annuities instead of Social Security benefits. To qualify for an RRB annuity, a worker must generally have at least 10 years of covered railroad work. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers benefits for railroad workers. To qualify for an RRB annuity, a worker needs at least 10 years of covered railroad work. RRB annuities are equivalent to or greater than Social Security benefits. There are two components: tier I and tier II, with tier I amounts similar to Social Security benefits and tier II retirement amounts paid separately. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers benefits for railroad workers, requiring at least 10 years of covered railroad work to qualify for an RRB annuity. These annuities consist of tier I and tier II components, with tier I amounts increasing annually with a cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) similar to Social Security benefits. Tier II retirement amounts are paid in addition to tier I amounts and are based solely on covered railroad service. Surviving spouses of railroad workers may be eligible for widow or widower annuities from RRB, which are generally higher than comparable Social Security benefits due to the inclusion of tier II amounts. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers benefits for railroad workers, requiring at least 10 years of covered railroad work to qualify for an RRB annuity. RRB survivor annuities are generally higher than comparable Social Security benefits, including tier II amounts. Surviving spouses may be eligible for up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity at full retirement age. Widows and widowers may receive a reduced annuity as early as age 60. A widow(er) caring for a deceased worker's child under age 16 may receive an annuity of up to 75% of the worker's tier I amount plus 100% of the worker's tier II amount. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widow(er)s. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 (P.L. 107-90) increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widow(er)s. Other provisions included investment options for retirement funds, removing early retirement reduction for employees with 30 years of experience, reducing vesting years for tier II annuities, repealing annuity limitations, and changing the tier II tax structure. These changes apply to widow(er)s receiving annuities from February 2002 onwards. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 increased initial annuities for qualifying widow(er)s of railroad employees. The new rules also apply to some widow(er)s who began receiving annuities before February 2002. The 2001 law added a new guaranty amount to increase initial annuities for qualifying widow(er)s. The 2001 law increased annuities for qualifying widow(er)s of railroad employees by adding a supplemental guaranty amount. The total initial minimum amount under current law is 100% of the tier I and tier II amounts the employee would have received, with annual increases based on Social Security COLA. The 2001 law increased annuities for qualifying widow(er)s of railroad employees by adding a supplemental guaranty amount. Tier I and regular tier II amounts are increased annually based on Social Security COLA, with the guaranty amount offsetting the COLA increase. This results in a constant monthly annuity for several years, which declines in real terms due to inflation. Once the guaranty amount reaches zero, the widow(er) will see an increase in their total monthly annuity. The 2001 law increased annuities for qualifying widow(er)s of railroad employees by adding a supplemental guaranty amount. Tier I and regular tier II annuities continue to increase each year by the applicable COLA. Widow(er)s now receive annuities greater than under prior law, with average annuity amounts rising from $1,138 to $1,416 per month in real 2005 dollars. An illustration shows how widow(er) annuities are calculated under current and prior law for a widow reaching full retirement age after her husband's death in 2006. Under current law, a widow who reached full retirement age after her husband's death in 2006 would receive an initial minimum amount of $1,300 per month, which is $150 more than under prior law. This increase is due to the addition of a guaranty amount to her regular annuity. The total annuity will not increase due to COLAs until her tier I and regular tier II amounts exceed the initial minimum. The widow's total annuity amount is $150 more than under prior law due to the addition of a guaranty amount to her regular annuity. Her total annuity will not increase due to COLAs until her tier I and regular tier II amounts exceed the initial minimum. The components of her annuity change each year, with her tier I amount increasing by $23 and her regular tier II amount increasing by $1 annually. The widow's guaranty amount decreases by $24 each year, resulting in a total tier II annuity under current law. Under current law, the widow's total monthly annuity would be $1,323 in 2012, higher than her 2011 annuity amount of $1,300. Starting in 2012, her tier I and regular tier II amounts would begin to exceed her initial minimum amount, as her guaranty amount gradually declines each year to offset the annual COLA. Starting in 2012, the widow's total monthly annuity would be $1,323 under current law, higher than her 2011 amount of $1,300. The annuity amount remains the same under both current and prior law, with adjustments for the annual COLA. Under current law, the widow's total annuity in 2006 is $1,300, consisting of tier I, tier II, and guaranty amounts. The guaranty amount decreases each year after 2006 as tier I and tier II amounts increase due to an annual offset.
